p:
Internationally comparative studies of
individual adaptation [ 108, 109] suggest protective behaviours to improve resilience to cold, such as clothing and central heating, are more common in colder regions. Changes in such behaviours over time in the UK may have contributed to reductions in cold weather mortality in London [ 110]. Case study research [ 111] shows some individuals take what they consider effective health protective measures during extreme weather events. However, there is little research on whether such behaviour is widespread among those most at risk in the UK population, and it is recognised that public information campaigns may have limited effect [ 7]. One UK study [ 36] cited in an international review [ 112] showed participants were unaware they were at particular risk due to hot weather.
